title: Scott Graves - Went to the Crossroads: What Really Matters in our Towns and Cities
description:
Scott Graves is a fellow Gardner-ite, head of SM Graves Associates, and hosts two very interesting podcasts, "Are We Here Yet?," and "Scotts on the Rocks" about local business and politics. 

We talked about the history of our country's financialization, the closing of once-thriving factories, the great skill and intelligence of everyday working people, and breaking the cycle of social and political disengagement. In the end, it was all about the life, death, and possibility of life again for small cities and towns like ours. 

00:30 – Introduction: A touring musician and looking for a sense of place
16:32 – The bizarre, theatrical, crisis-ridden national scene
24:28 – When the voters feel powerless
29:00 – TheCommonToad confesses lifelong ignorance of local politics
31:57 – The widespread cynicism of civic participation
36:34 – The slow death of our mill towns: highly skilled citizens are abandoned by their industries
43:35 – We take a moment to jeer at the Democratic party's snobbery towards working people
52:59 – Scott explains the economics that bring small industrial cities to this moment
1:05:59 – As the financial-ization of the economy progresses, what happens to workers in small cities and towns?
1:11:46 – What strategies do communities have to fight back?
1:21:05 – Provincial or parochial? Wendell Berry and loving your location
1:32:05 – What is Scott working on now? Worcshop, “Are we here yet?” and a little Blues slips in...

For more links related to this conversation, visit: https://www.thecommontoad.com/single-post/conversations-scott-graves-went-to-the-crossroads-what-really-matters-in-our-towns-and-cities
